p: We conducted a mixed-methods study with qualitative (FGDs) and quantitative (18 item survey questionnaire) data collection. Mixed-methods research seeks to integrate and triangulate findings from qualitative and quantitative methods. Its pragmatic focus contrasts with methodologic purism [ 12]. Compared to monomethod studies, convergence of findings stemming from two or more methods may enhance the belief that the results are valid (multiple operationalism) [ 13]. Previous authors have highlighted the value of such real-time data collection that examines real-time emergent trends and integrates community attitudes, behaviors, and responses into epidemiological research [ 14].
